The collaborative is now known as the Truist Corporation and processes close to 2 billion dollars for local United Ways and other organizations.

Consultant  - Interim VP Finance / CFO
August 30, 2012, Arnold reported directly to Brian

Brian Hassett is a natural and charismatic leader. Brian’s intelligence and leadership qualities were put to the test while he led the United Way of Metropolitan Chicago. The region was served by two UW organizations, city and suburban, and Brian challenged this less than optimal alliance. The cost of doing business in this manner was unacceptable to Brian and needed to be changed.  Politically but correctly, Brian chose the path of most-resistance – merger. With the support of the national organization, United Way of America, Brian was able to effectively make the case that in addition to cost cutting already completed by the Chicago organization, the synergies gained by merger would allow significantly more costs to be reduced thereby providing a more compelling (to donors) cost structure in the region. Brian also took a leadership role in challenging the way donations are counted when they simply pass through United Way to a competitor organization. Brian called this double counting misleading, resulting in “phantom revenues” that improperly reduced the expense to revenue ratio in various cities and inflating the national impact of United Way.  Brian’s vocal and effective leadership helped establish much needed reforms and improved transparency in revenue reporting

summary: Strong non profit sector leadership and management experience. Strategic planning background. Fund development and marketing specialty. Experience as Chief Executive Officer of six organizations. CEO of four United Way organizations including Phoenix, Arizona and Chicago, Illinois. Co-Founder of United eWay, a consortium of 65 United Way's utilizing a common pledge capture and processing system which later became the system used by United Way of America. This project was later incorporated as Truist Corporation and now Frontstream and processes close to 2.24 billion dollars. Founder of GuitarMania Phoenix, the largest public art project in the history of the State of Arizona featuring close to 100 ten foot tall Fender Stratocaster Guitars as pieces of art spread throughout the Valley of the Sun. In three years this project raised over $1,000,000 for Big Brothers Big Sisters in sponsorship and auctions. Specialties: board development, fundraising, marketing, strategic planning, organizational development, special event fund raising, endowment, major gifts, planned giving. Donated Goods markets.Non profit marketing and relationships with advertising agencies - numerous Addy Awards and in 1997, while President and CEO of Valley of the Sun United Way won an International Clio Award.
